headline: Alabama law criminalizing gender transition surgery, drugs for minors takes effect
sentences: The Arkansas legislature passed a similar law banning doctors from prescribing the drugs in March, but courts said it was overly broad and the state's Republican governor, Asa Hutchinson, vetoed it in early April.
The law makes it punishable by up to ten years in prison to provide puberty blockers, hormone treatments, or transition surgery to anyone under 19 years old.
The groups have sought to block the bill from taking effect while the litigation is ongoing, but a judge on Sunday made no indication of taking the action.
Ivey also signed a law banning certain elementary school teachers from discussing gender identity and sexual orientation in school last month.
The law is very similar to legislation passed in Florida banning teachers from teaching on the issues between kindergarten and third grade.
An Alabama law making it a felony to provide puberty blockers or perform gender transition surgery on minors took effect Monday.
Alabama is the second state to attempt a ban on the use of puberty blockers and hormones on minors.
The law has faces several challenges from transgender groups.
Critics dubbed the legislation, signed by Republican Gov.
Ron DeSantis, as the "don't say gay" bill.
Kay Ivey signed the law in early April.
